pros: professors are nice and understanding they want to help you

cons: The pay was horrible. They expected me to run the library with a salary barely above minimum wage.

pros: Wonderful and nice people. Student focused university. Excellent side benefits if you have time to use them.

pros: It's a good job for a student

pros: Wonderful community at UP--the people really care! Have never been happier in a job.

pros: I enjoyed the people I worked with and everyone was really laid back most of the time.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Computer Science in Portland, OR
pros: fantastic colleagues, bright and engaged students

pros: really flexible for students, supervisors work with you to work around your class schedule
cons: limited job opportunities, priority given to students with work study

review_title: Good Work Life Balance, but Lacks Vision
pros: The work/life balance is amazing. Tuition remission if you want to go back to school or have college-age children and many other universities participate in the tuition exchange. Ability to audit classes. Most employees are incredibly kind, smart and want to collaborate. The fitness center is available to employees and that is very nice.
cons: Very stuck in their ways. Many employees are "lifers" and do not want to be challenged, try new things, or work with others that have different points of view. Diversity and Inclusion are also a big problem. No paid family leave, which is at odds with the values of Catholicism.

pros: I was a first year workshop leader during the fall semester of 2021. The job had a very fun work environment and the supervisors were helpful.
cons: Thinking back to my time as a first year workshop leader, I do not have any cons for this position because I had a great experience

job_title: Residence Hall Director in Portland, OR
pros: This job is super fun with lots of autonomy.
cons: After a while you might desire some more regularity in your schedule.

review_title: a good place to work, in the right department

review_title: A lot of opportunity for improvement

cons: Administration cannot be trusted. Although some administrators have been removed, a couple unsavory senior administrators remain.

review_title: You need to be on the right team
pros: Great retirement benefits and the fellow BIPOC and allies I worked with.
cons: Lacking the knowledge and investment in learning how to address the systematic racism that plagues this institution.

review_title: smaller school - sense of community a plus

review_title: Good program to work for until the pandemic hit and they did not handle it well.

cons: The school threw me under the bus during the pandemic.

pros: flexible time, understanding managers, projects help a future career in data analytics

pros: Great school, I actively go there and work there part time in the School of Nursing Simulation Lab. Very accommodating and helpful, never makes me feel uncomfortable.
cons: I wish this virus was over then I could go to school normally at this awesome campus.

job_title: Assistant Building Mechanic in Portland, OR
pros: Flexible work hours, friendly coworkers, low-stress environment, safe environment, opportunity to learn practical skills.
cons: Hard work sometimes goes unnoticed, especially by administration.

review_title: Great working environment but low pay
pros:
Great work-life balance with only working around 35 hours a week.
Supervisors are very understanding and treat you with respect.
cons:
Low salaries. If you negotiate for a higher salary, HR usually declines. 
Limited growth opportunities.

review_title: Great Place to Start in College Athletics
pros: Staff is very easy to work with and constantly striving to improve everything they do. Full-time employees get 95% tuition remission on all offered master's degrees!
cons: You'll be working long hours and lots of weekends for average pay.

review_title: Lots of helping patrons with software/hardware
pros: Can do homework on the job
cons: Lots of downtime and supervising

pros: Friendly work environment with good communication
cons: Low starting pay and low hours

pros: Flexible work time to work around schedule
cons: There are not too many downsides

pros: I was a student worker and got minimum wage.
cons: I was a student worker.

pros:
Earn money while going to school
Get expereince
cons: They do not pay enough

review_title: You do far more than you are hired to do
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn new things. People are wonderful. Feeling of giving back to your community is definitely fulfilled. Beautiful campus with students who are very bright.  Benefits are great. Healthcare plan is very good, house down payment if you buy within a certain distance of the university is forgiven after 5 years, and 11% match for your 401k. Work hours 8:30am-4:30pm, 35 hours M-F is considered full time.
cons: Pay doesn't come even close to the industry average. You're paid less than other universities for the same position. Most people don't stay more than 2 years unless they have income from somewhere else or a partner to share costs. Your job description at the beginning may not include everything you eventually end up doing over time. Because people are constantly leaving you have to pick up other people's jobs to complete tasks. Sometimes a new person isn't hired right away so you end up doing a lot but you are not compensated for additional work added to your already packed 7 hour day. That's why people leave. Overtime is very rare.

pros: They have a good sense of community.
cons: My hours are based on student activity.

pros: Community, dedicated staff, beautiful campus and good benefits
cons: Salary, lack of advocacy for staff

pros: Students are phenomenal, energetic, and passionate
cons: Leadership needs to work on improving the climate for employees

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Portland, OR
pros: The benefits seem quite competitive.  Healthcare is through Kaiser if desired, and the retirement package for salaried workers is quite nice (as long as you stick around for a while).  The campus is Catholic, so if you like a religious environment, it's great.  The professors and the students are  friendly.  The University is in a nice neighborhood.  The gym on campus was just recently built, and employees have free access.  The major benefit is educational discounts for family.  There are also quite a few events on campus at which dinners and lunches are catered.
cons: Traffic in Portland is getting to be increasingly bad, and the neighborhood that the university is in is getting to be much more expensive.  Sometimes hours can be a bit long, but such is the life of a teacher.

review_title: Great organization with room for improvement
pros: The people at the university were the best part of my experience. The majority of staff and faculty I interacted with had the student's best interests at heart. I loved the beautiful environment of the campus and partaking in conversations with others about ideas and issues.
cons: I think the university is in a difficult position trying to balance their values about supporting all students ("fostering a supportive, inclusive community and an accessible campus culture"), with their faith. For example, I attended a workshop on campus focused on organizational culture. The presenter was leading a discussion on pronouns and how they can be used by professors to create a more inclusive classroom at the beginning of each term. One of the priests in attendance raised concern about university staff and faculty affirming beliefs on gender identity that were inconsistent with the catholic church's beliefs. This is just one example, but highlights how it can be a difficult position for an institution to be inclusive if it's sponsoring institution is not.

pros: Caring community of peers. Faculty salaries are improving and transparency around salaries/benefits is increasing. 11% retirement contributions. Diversity of student body and faculty are low but improving.
cons: Faculty salaries, especially in CAS/Ed simply do not reflect the cost of living. Even tenure-track faculty are struggling to pay rent in Portland. Culture of upper administration (traditional/conservative/religious) is at odds with most faculty and students, and with the city it is located in.

pros: Great colleagues who are committed to helping students. Continued growth in applications and student attendance. Organization prides itself on doing more with less. In good shape financially.
cons: The administration is out of touch with many of the issues facing employees. Lower salaries compared to other colleges in the area. No flexibility and a lack of understanding for working parents. No additional hiring even as student population grows.

review_title: Avoid if you love yourself and your family
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Portland, OR
pros: The view and nothing more
cons: Campus safety management is terrible. They gossip they lie and are very lazy. No managers no director. They bully and pick on good employees. Terrible uniforms. Awful hours. The incompetence is not worth 20 an hour. If you’re lazy and want zero help from managers this is the place for you. If I could give this less than zero I would. Bad leaders.

review_title: Taking care of all marketing in print, on the web and social media.
pros: Boss was not a micromanager. Free to bring ideas to light. Lots of great and wonderful people to work with.
cons: Wages are well below average and your plate is always far to full of projects. But you will learn a lot from this experience.

job_title: Assistant Director, Moreau Center for Service and Justice in Portland, OR
pros: Working with students to coordinate service and justice projects, addressing social justice issues, mentoring students, working with some amazing faculty and staff
cons: U.P. is a Roman Catholic school that depends on the Congregation of Holy Cross. The president has to be a Holy Cross priest, and he appoints key administrative positions. It is classic nepotism.

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Portland, OR
pros: The community is small enough to know most of the people you may come across on any given day. Benefits are above most industry standards.
cons: Set in their ways, hard to affect change. Always playing catch-up to issues. Not very forward thinking. Almost no room for advancement

job_title: Computer Lab Tech in Portland, OR
pros: There were always new things to do.  Working in an academic setting also allowed for high levels of networking.  Good Job
cons: There were certain times when things got a bit too busy.  Not really a bad thing, but hey, something had to go here.

review_title: Treated as a professional, expected the same
pros: Efficient and qualified management team. Worked with the students to find a schedule that benefited both the university, the staff, and the students.
cons: personal growth is relatively limited from a student worker's position, but this is a relatively common expectation of the situation, being used to a high employee turnover (since the position can last for a maximum of 4 years).

pros: The athletic department is full of committed individuals who strive for UP to be the best in the West Coast Conference. The Nike connection is definitely a plus and I certainly miss that portion of my job.
cons: At that time the volleyball program was in a transition and so it made life a little frustrating at times. Long hours and minimal compensation.

pros: Great, relaxing environment. Colleagues and supervisor very helpful and supportive. School understands the balance of work/academics and easy to change schedule if conflicts arise.
cons: Some of the jobs aren't really advertised that great, likely due to budget cuts, so you kinda have to be checking the job board at the right time.

job_title: Computer Lab Tech in Portland, OR
pros:
- Access to dining hall, gym, sporting events, etc...
- My boss as a computer tech is great with college students and is very friendly.
cons: The University pays  all of their work-study workers minimum wage which is a little confusing as attending school is so expensive.

job_title: Telephone Outreach Program Caller in Portland, OR
pros: It's a great way to stay on campus as a student and make some money on the side.
cons: It's not a job for you if you're not a people person. You have to talk on the phone with people for three hours and sometimes they're rude but you can't let it get to you.

pros: A collegial and friendly setting with high caliber students. Supervision of students both undergraduate and graduate is an excellent experience. Coaching students as they work to become licensed teachers is interesting and challenging.
cons: I can't think of any negatives. It is very interesting.

pros: A comfortable environment where you can focus on your studies while gaining work experience.
cons: A little too laid back for some people. This environment is not for those looking to really kick start a career, rather a student with other priorities and aspirations.

job_title: Climbing Wall Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Small department where you can make a difference, flexibility with work schedule, opportunity to develop personal skills. Probably the best job on campus
cons: There are high expectations for student workers. Not a good job if you are just looking to do homework

pros:

pros: The folks at UP are very nice to work with. The retirement plan is really competitive with a 11% employer contribution.
cons: There is no room for promotion or growth within your position.

pros: Great place to work with faculty, staff and students that care and try to do the right thing!
cons: It's maybe 1.2 miles to the MAX lines, but bus transportation and bikes work great as alternatives.

review_title: Office Assistant at Office of Financial Aid
pros: Great team work environment! I loved this job, working as a student worker all through college!

job_title: Public Safety Dispatcher in Portland, OR
pros: Location, nothing else is really great about this place.
cons: Poor leadership, stressful environment management doesn’t like people who actually work.

pros: Regular salary increase, great people, faith oriented, beautiful campus, opportunities for graduate school tuition coverage, colleagues are friendly and supportive of work.

pros: Staffs are very supportive and helpful.

pros: Nice grounds, good benefits, friendly coworkers

pros: benefits, sick pay, holiday pay
cons: pay, pay, pay, pay, pay

pros: Wonderful faculty, across the board.
